body.p:
To His Excellincy Thomas E Bramlette
Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky

Your Petitioner Robert Davis would Respectfully represent unto your Excillency That he was at the Present March Term of the Laurel Circuit Court 1865 fined twenty dollars for retailing that the Circumstances under which he was Indicted & fined were as follows That in the Spring of 1864 he was working at a Military Post near London Ky. and one day he was requested by Pitman who was a Tavern keeper to waiting on any one calling at the bar for a short time and your Petitioner ^not^ thinking of violating Law did go behind the Counter and sell one or two drinks of whisky as a matter of accomodation for said Pitman without realizing or Expecting to realize one cents he was not Sworn as required by law but did not know that it was contrary to law to sell for a Licensed Tavern Keeper withuot being Sworn that he knew but little of the Laws of this State as he was driven by this rebelion from Tenissee his native State a Short time after the Commencement of the Present war
for no other reason than that he could not & would not be a tra traitor to his country He Says that he is a very poor man and a law abiding citizen & thinks it very hard to be made pay a fine for violating a law which he did not know was in Existince or he would not have done so
The premises considered He prays that your Excillency remit said fine and he promises not to ask a similar favor Again
The undersigned believe the Statements of the foregoing Petition and Heartily join in the prayer thereof

R. Boyd
W P Evans
H L Blakely
Jesse Randall
Hiram. Faris
R D Johnson
W H, Bottoms
Wm H Tompkins
C. B. Faris clk
Laurel Cir Court
Wm I Moren
W. K. Johnson
N. B. Jones
Thos. J. Canifax
I hope that you will remit this

Laurel Co
vs
Wiley Green
$50
4th May/65
